briefings.summary: NVDA closed Friday at $189.82 (+1.02%). No market-moving news Monday pre-open. Q4 FY26 earnings due Wednesday Feb 25 AMC — the critical near-term catalyst. Morningstar rates NVDA 4-star undervalued with $240 fair value estimate. Consensus expects ~$65B revenue and EPS $1.53.

stocks.note: $189.82 (Friday close). Earnings Wed Feb 25 AMC. Consensus $65B rev, EPS $1.53. Morningstar FV $240. Blackwell ramp + AI data center demand are the key narratives.

briefings.analysis: NVDA enters earnings week in reasonable shape — recovering from the $185 lows and closing Friday at $189.82. The Feb 25 Q4 FY26 report is the biggest near-term catalyst in the entire portfolio watchlist. Morningstar sees the stock as moderately undervalued at a $240 fair value. Analyst consensus sits around $65B revenue and $1.53 EPS with a high historical beat rate (~94.5%). Bull case: Blackwell supercycle beats + strong Q1 guide to $75B+ → re-rating toward $250. Bear case: China export headwinds, circular AI demand concerns, Q1 guide disappoints at ~$70B → pullback to $150 support. Implied volatility is elevated heading into the event — expect a significant post-earnings move either direction. The result will also set the tone for SOXX and the broader AI infrastructure trade including CRWV, NBIS, and IREN in the portfolio.

CRWV bouncing +3% despite class action lawsuit filing. MU surging on Zacks #1 Strong Buy with 4 analyst upgrades. FCX got double upgrade (Freedom Capital Buy/$76 PT, Scotiabank raised to $72). MSFT drifting lower on AI capex concerns. NBIS slightly down but confirmed acquisition of Tavily (AI agent software). CIFR reports earnings TOMORROW (Feb 24).

briefings.analysis: Today is dominated by the Bitcoin crash — BTC broke below $65,000 support for the first time in weeks, dropping to a $64,384 intraday low on tariff tensions, regulatory uncertainty, and heavy whale selling. This is the 6th consecutive negative week for crypto. The ripple effect hits FBTC (-3%), IREN (-4%), and CIFR (-2%) hard — and CIFR reports earnings TOMORROW, making this especially sensitive. CRWV is the surprise gainer (+3%) despite BFA Law filing a class action lawsuit alleging securities fraud. The stock is recovering from an $84.50 intraday low, suggesting buyers ahead of Thursday earnings. MU is surging on a Zacks #1 Strong Buy call + 4 upward analyst estimate revisions. FCX got a double-upgrade day (Freedom Capital Buy/$76, Scotiabank/$72) as copper fundamentals stay strong. NBIS dipped slightly but confirmed its Tavily acquisition, deepening its AI software stack. NVDA reports tomorrow — that result will set the tone for SOXX and the entire AI infrastructure trade.

stocks.note: $186.50. Down on tech rotation. Q4 FY26 earnings Feb 25 AMC. Consensus EPS $1.52.

briefings.analysis: NVDA continues to drift lower from $190+ levels as the tech-to-value rotation persists. The Feb 25 earnings report is the next major catalyst — Blackwell ramp and AI data center demand will determine direction. Stock is approaching a key support zone around $185. Elevated implied volatility heading into the event.

FCX was the bright spot at +2.83% on copper rally. AMPX surged +4.4%. MSFT flat at $397.23. MU dipped slightly. BTC holding ~$68.9K keeping FBTC stable. CIFR earnings Monday Feb 24, CRWV earnings Thursday Feb 26.

Key catalysts ahead: CIFR earnings Feb 24, CRWV earnings Feb 26. The rotation out of high-beta AI names into value/commodities continued today.

FBTC +0.73% as BTC stabilizes. AI infra names (CRWV, NBIS, IREN) pulled back slightly on sector rotation concerns. CIFR flat pre-earnings. AMPX dipped on profit-taking after defense partnership rally.

The AI infra complex (CRWV, NBIS, IREN) saw mild profit-taking — a TipRanks report flagged sector rotation concerns. CRWV earnings Feb 25 is the next major catalyst. NBIS named Zacks Bull of the Day with 508% expected revenue growth. Portfolio remains well-positioned for AI/crypto themes despite near-term rotation noise.

briefings.summary: Mixed session — S&P 500 -0.56%, Nasdaq -0.60% on hawkish Fed minutes and geopolitical tensions. Despite broad weakness, AI/crypto names bucked the trend. NBIS led the portfolio +5.7%, AMPX +4.4%. CRWV +1.8% ahead of Feb 25 earnings. Semis (SOXX) and mega-cap (MSFT) dipped. MU gave back gains but Mar 19 earnings loom. BTC names recovered (FBTC +1.3%, CIFR +2.5%, IREN +2.9%).

briefings.analysis: Portfolio outperformed the broader market today despite S&P/Nasdaq weakness. AI infrastructure (NBIS +5.7%, AMPX +4.4%, CRWV +1.8%) and crypto recovery (FBTC, CIFR, IREN all green) offset losses in semis and mega-cap tech. The hawkish Fed minutes and strong labor data suggest rates stay higher for longer, which pressures growth multiples but the AI capex cycle remains the dominant theme. Key upcoming catalysts: CRWV earnings Feb 25 and MU earnings Mar 19.

briefings.summary: NVDA trading ~$185 after pulling back from $190+ levels. Earnings Feb 25 (6 days). Meta chip deal positive catalyst. DeepSeek rotation weighing on mega-cap tech.

stocks.note: ~$185, pulled back from $190. Q4 FY26 earnings Feb 25. Meta chip deal bullish but DeepSeek rotation headwind.

briefings.analysis: NVDA is the sole watchlist ticker and faces a critical earnings catalyst on Feb 25. The stock has declined from $190+ to ~$185 amid the broader tech-to-value rotation sparked by DeepSeek. However, AI data center demand remains exceptionally strong — Meta just announced a massive NVDA chip order. Consensus EPS is $1.52. Blackwell platform ramp is the key narrative. High-conviction earnings play with elevated vol expected.

CRWV continues climbing ahead of its Q4 earnings report on Feb 26 (key event). Semis held strong with SOXX gaining ~1%. MSFT traded ex-dividend and drifted slightly lower. Two earnings reports within 7 days: CIFR (Feb 24) and CRWV (Feb 26) — both high-conviction events to watch.

MU was the big winner at +5.3%. Semis rallied on Meta-NVDA chip deal. FCX boosted by Grasberg extension MOU. IREN sold off post-earnings despite AI pivot progress.

briefings.analysis: Tech led the market higher with semis the standout sector. MU surged 5.3% on renewed AI/HBM demand optimism after Meta announced a massive NVDA chip order. FCX got a major catalyst — Indonesia agreed to extend Grasberg operating rights for life of resource, huge for long-term copper production. BTC names (FBTC, CIFR, IREN) lagged as Bitcoin struggles around $67K. IREN took the biggest hit post-earnings — revenue missed but the AI cloud pivot ($3.4B ARR target) remains on track. Fed minutes showed deep divisions on rate cuts vs holds, keeping uncertainty elevated. PCE data Friday could be the next catalyst.

market.title: S&P 500 Concentration Risk: 10 Stocks = 40% of Index
market.description: The S&P 500's top 10 holdings represent nearly 40% of total index weight. With these names underperforming during the current rotation, the index itself is masking significant internal weakness. The market bounced Friday to close just above its 20-day moving average — fragile technical positioning heading into Monday.
market.thesis: Index investors are getting a distorted picture. The equal-weight S&P is outperforming significantly, but passive mega-cap exposure carries hidden rotation risk. If the rotation exhausts AND tech fails to recover, the headline index could see a sharp drawdown. Monitor whether SPY can hold above its 20-day MA this week — failure is a bearish signal.

market.title: GE Aerospace & Industrial Momentum Stocks Leading Mid-Cap Breakouts
market.description: Within the industrials rotation, GE Aerospace (GE) holds a Zacks #1 Strong Buy rank and is benefiting directly from the sector tailwind. Pollution Control and Metal Fabricating sub-sectors are the strongest pockets within Industrials. Transportation index recently peaked 3 standard deviations above mean after a massive post-Liberation Day rally — entering a short-term correction phase.
market.thesis: GE Aerospace represents the highest-conviction name within the industrials rotation — strong fundamentals meeting a strong sector tailwind. However, the broader Transportation Index is showing exhaustion after its massive run. The opportunity window in industrials may be narrowing; focus on quality names like GE rather than chasing the sector ETF.

market.title: Tech & Financials Deeply Oversold — Contrarian Accumulation Zone
market.description: XLK (Technology) is oversold and trading at significant discounts to expected growth rates. XLF (Financials) is 3 standard deviations BELOW its mean — a rare extreme. With mega-cap tech comprising 29% of the S&P, any reversal of the rotation creates an outsized snapback opportunity.
market.thesis: The same breadth extremes that make cyclicals dangerous make oversold tech and financials interesting. Micron (MU) holds a Zacks Strong Buy rating within semiconductors. When the reflation narrative cracks under falling inflation data, capital will rush back to growth. Quality tech at depressed relative multiples is the contrarian play.

market.title: Cyclical Sector Breadth at 50-Year Extremes — Exhaustion Risk
market.description: Energy, Materials, Industrials, and Staples are trading 3+ standard deviations above their means on breadth measures. This level of overbought extension in slower-growth defensives and cyclical inflation hedges hasn't been seen in 50 years. Meanwhile, macro data is showing slowing growth and falling inflation — directly undermining the reflation trade thesis.
market.thesis: When cyclicals are priced for sustained inflation but macro data shows the opposite, the disconnect tends to resolve violently. Rotation reversal could be swift. Monitor breadth indicators — this is a late-cycle signal, not a launchpad. Reduce exposure to crowded defensives.

market.title: Great Rotation: Value vs. Growth Bifurcation
market.description: A pronounced sector split is reshaping 2026 YTD. Energy (+21%), Materials (+17%), Staples (+15%), and Industrials (+12%) are massively outperforming while Tech, Financials, and Healthcare lag. The S&P 500 is up only ~1.2% YTD as mega-cap tech weight (29% of index) drags on the headline number.
market.thesis: Structural broadening away from a decade of mega-cap tech dominance. The Dow Transports hitting new highs confirms broad economic resilience outside large-cap growth. However, the four outperforming sectors represent only ~19% of the S&P 500 — the math limits how far this rotation can lift the index.

market.title: Seasonal Pattern: February Weak, March Recovery
market.description: February historically shows ~50% positive months with flat-to-negative average returns. March typically sees recovery as markets prep for a bullish Q2. Year 2 post-election cycles average 3.1-6.2% annual returns.
market.thesis: Don't panic on February weakness — it's seasonal. Patient capital gets rewarded in March. This is a rotation, not a correction. Broad-based gains expected as the year progresses.

market.title: AI Capex Fatigue — Tech Under Pressure
market.description: Mega-cap tech is losing favor as investors question ROI timelines on AI infrastructure spending. Alphabet's $20B bond sale raised red flags. The Mag 7 concentration trade is unwinding.
market.thesis: This rotation could accelerate if Q1 earnings show AI spending without proportional revenue growth. Tech isn't dead but the easy money phase is over. Relevant for Jordan's MSFT position — monitor for further weakness.

market.title: Caterpillar Riding Energy Transition Wave
market.description: CAT up 32% YTD — the top industrial performer. Benefiting from sustainable energy transition capex and infrastructure spending. Leading the industrial sector's contribution to broader market gains.
market.thesis: Energy transition requires heavy equipment and power infrastructure. CAT and GEV are the picks-and-shovels play on the green transition. Stretched valuations are a concern but the secular trend is intact.

market.title: Energy Sector Dominance — Oil +12% YTD
market.description: Energy is the best-performing sector in 2026, up 22%+ YTD. XOM up 26%, fair value raised to $142. Oil prices surged ~12% since Jan 1, providing sustained tailwinds for the entire sector.
market.thesis: Oil momentum + rotation from tech = energy keeps running. XOM's upgraded fair value suggests fundamental support, not just momentum. Watch for pullbacks as entry points — current levels are extended.

market.title: The Great Rotation: Tech → Real Economy
market.description: Capital is flowing out of mega-cap tech into industrials, energy, and consumer defensives. AI capex fatigue is driving investors to question ROI on massive infrastructure spending. Alphabet's $20B bond sale on Feb 10 intensified concerns.
market.thesis: This isn't a blip — it's a structural shift. Investors want earnings NOW, not AI promises. Energy up 22% YTD, industrials driving broader market gains. However, none of these leaders are undervalued per Morningstar, so chasing here is risky.

market.title: Late-February Seasonal Dip Incoming
market.description: Historical seasonality shows late-February weakness before a March recovery. Year 2 of presidential cycle averages -19.4% max drawdown. Value sector overbought extremes and tech oversold conditions suggest a tactical pullback is likely before Q2 rally.
market.thesis: Overbought value + oversold tech + seasonal weakness = near-term volatility risk. This is not a time to chase. Patience rewards — historical data shows strong Q2 recoveries. Use any dip to position for the March-April rebound.

market.title: Consumer Staples Renaissance
market.description: Consumer Staples surged from Very Unattractive to Attractive rating in rapid fashion, up +15% YTD. Defensive positioning accelerating as late-cycle concerns mount and growth expectations moderate.
market.thesis: Staples outperformance signals the market is pricing in economic deceleration. This sector provides downside protection while still capturing upside from improving fundamentals. Classic late-cycle positioning.

market.title: Oversold Tech — Selective AI Chip Plays
market.description: Technology is oversold relative to 50-day MA despite fundamentals rated Very Attractive. AI chip demand remains strong. Micron (MU) carries top analyst rank. The selloff creates entry points in quality names ahead of earnings season.
market.thesis: Tech is getting thrown out with the bathwater in the rotation trade. AI infrastructure spending is not slowing — selective semiconductor names at oversold levels offer asymmetric risk/reward for a snap-back into Q2.

market.title: Industrials Breakout — GE Aerospace Leading
market.description: Industrials rated Very Attractive with strong breadth. Pollution Control and Metal Fabricating sub-industries leading. GE Aerospace carries top analyst rank. Dow Transports hitting new highs confirms broad economic optimism.
market.thesis: Industrials benefit from infrastructure spending, reshoring trends, and defense budgets. Sector breadth is extreme — nearly all stocks trading above key moving averages. GE Aerospace is a best-in-class play on aviation and defense demand.

market.title: The Great Rotation: Value Over Tech
market.description: Capital is aggressively rotating out of Technology into Energy (+21% YTD), Materials (+17%), Consumer Staples (+15%), and Industrials (+12%). Tech is the worst-performing sector in 2026, reversing years of dominance. Value sectors occupy only ~19% of S&P 500 but their breadth is offsetting tech weakness.
market.thesis: This is a structural rotation, not a blip. Late-cycle dynamics favor value/defensives as growth slows and rates ease. The 24pp performance gap between best and worst sectors signals sustained capital reallocation away from mega-cap tech concentration.

market.title: Value Sector Overbought — Watch for Pullback
market.description: Energy, Materials, and Industrials are showing extreme overbought conditions relative to historical deviations from 50-day MAs. Growth is slowing, wages falling, and rates declining — which could undermine the reflation trade narrative.
market.thesis: The reflation trade depends on inflation staying elevated and growth remaining steady. Recent data shows both weakening. If this trade unwinds, overbought value sectors could see a sharp mean-reversion pullback. Consider trimming or hedging positions that have run hard.

market.title: Utilities & REITs — Dividend Flight to Safety
market.description: XLU surged 2.8% and XLRE gained 1.5% on Feb 17. Investors rotating to dividend-yielding assets as growth concerns emerge. Fed Funds Rate paused at 3.64% makes stable dividends attractive.
market.thesis: With the Fed paused and tech under pressure, yield-bearing sectors offer both safety and upside. Data center REITs could benefit from AI inference buildout at the edge. This trade works in both soft-landing and mild-recession scenarios.

market.title: GE Aerospace — Industrials Leader
market.description: GE Aerospace carries Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) within the Industrials sector, which just rose to Very Attractive rating. Pollution Control and Metal Fabricating sub-industries strongest. Benefits from reflation trade and infrastructure spending.
market.thesis: Industrials showing very high breadth — most stocks trading above 50/100/200-day MAs. GE is a top-ranked pick in the hottest sector rotation. Defense + aerospace demand provides secular tailwind beyond just the cyclical trade.

market.title: Small-Cap Breakout — Russell 2000 Surging
market.description: Russell 2000 surged +5.4% vs large-caps +1.5%. Small caps benefiting from falling short-term rates (lower borrowing costs) and rotation out of mega-cap tech into domestically focused cyclicals.
market.thesis: Small caps are historically cheap relative to large caps. Falling rates reduce their borrowing costs, and the reflation trade favors domestic industrials and materials — exactly where small caps are concentrated. Could be early innings of a multi-quarter run.

market.title: The Great Rotation: Tech → Value
market.description: Massive sector rotation underway since DeepSeek AI Shock (Jan 27). Money flowing from mega-cap tech into Energy (+21% YTD), Materials (+17%), Industrials (+12%), and Staples (+15%). S&P 500 flat while value sectors surge. Nvidia lost $590B in one day.
market.thesis: DeepSeek proved AI can be trained cheaply, undermining high-capex tech valuations. Combined with the One Big Beautiful Bill Act tax cuts for domestic energy/manufacturing, the reflation trade is accelerating. This rotation could persist for months.
